bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to George A. Kellogg, February 20, 1941

div1.p: Hench sends Kellogg photographs to be used by Cornwell for changes to the yellow fever painting. He discusses Clara Maass, the Cubans' representation of Finlay's work, and a need for two versions of the painting to please both Americans and Cubans.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to George A. Kellogg, February 20, 1941
div1.opener:
February 20, 1941
Mr. George A. Kellogg
257 Cornelison Ave.
Jersey City, N. J.
My dear Mr. Kellogg:
div1.p:
Please pardon me for not writing you Monday. You recall I had to give a
talk at the University of Minnesota Friday. I found that it was to be published so I
had to spend the past two or three days writing it up. Hence my delay. Let me tell
you how interested I was in the visit of yourself and Mr. Withington. I must confess
I was a bit concerned when you wrote you were coming out. I was fearful lest your trip
here might be a waste of time and money, and your reassurances that you found my informa-
tion helpful make me hope that it was worth your while coming.

Most important: a group photo of the hospital corps at Camp Columbia,
Havana Cuba. This photo was taken Sept. 1900, the month that Lazear died. It shows
Lieut. Truby (now General Truby) who was acting commanding officer of the hospital. As
you can well imagine he will be of invaluable help in settling disputed points as he was
there and saw what went on and has a keen memory fortified by a diary. This photo was
taken on the shops of one of the hospital wards. If you will consult the two photos I
gave you (one of the officers' quarters and one of the “wards and operating room,” Post
Hospital, Columbia Barracks) you will recognize this building and stairs at once. Re-
member this photo is NOT the porch of the officers' quarters but the porch of one of the
wards. But I have no doubt the general architecture was about the same as the two photos
I gave you will show, and this photo gives a close up view not only of the type of
boarding, etc., but more important, of the uniforms worn by the men.

Lieutenant (notw General) Truby was an officer in the regular medical corps.
You will therefore note the difference between his uniform (he is #1 in the photo) and
that of Drs. Pinto (#2), Amador (#3) and Cooke (#4) who were all merely “Contract Surgeons”,
i.e. lay physicians hired from civil practice to act as army physicians in a temporary
capacity. Just why the uniforms of Drs. Pinto (white), Amador (khaki? with khaki?
shoulder straps) and Cooke (khaki with dark shoulder straps) should have differed I do
not know. Doubtless you can get the answer from Gen. Truby or Gen. Kean or find copies
of these uniforms in the War Dept. (Possibly from the Chief of the Signal Corps in
Washington as apparently the Signal Corps included the army photographers).

Note the varying uniforms of the noncommissioned officers in the second row.
But especially note figure #10 - Private Kissinger. You wanted a photo of him in 1900.
Here it is. John J. Moran, the other original volunteer is not in the photo because his
term of enlistment had expired and he was acting as a civilian clerk in Gen. Lee's head-
quarters. (Moran had been a noncommissioned officer, (acting hospital steward with rank of
sergeant) but was no longer in service when he volunteered to Major Reed. Hence, being
a civilian now, he was not in this photo. Remember that if Mr. Cornwell decides to
use him and Kissinger I suspect it would be justifiable artistic licence to put Moran back
in uniform if you wanted to; but to be historically accurate Moran was then in civilian
- 2 -
Mr. George A. Kellogg
February 20, 1941
clothes. There is another rather similar photo of Kissinger taken also in 1900 which
appears in a booklet “The Conquest of Yellow Fever” by James E. Peabody. Kissinger's
photo appears on page 9 and shows his uniform but he is here an acting hospital
steward (sergeant) not a private. (It is the same photo as in the Dodge Auto News
article which I enclose.) When he volunteered he was a private; as a result of his
bravery he was promoted to be a sergeant and this photo therefore was taken later than
the scene Mr. Cornwell will be painting. This same booklet contains another photo of
Dr. Carroll, a later one of Agramonte and the conventional ones of Reed, Lazear and
Finlay. Moran tells me he has no photos of himself taken in or near 1900 but I am
sending you 3 recent ones and you can compare them to one of him taken in the World
War when he was a captain. I think with a little imagination you can figure out
what he looked like in 1900 and I'm sure he'd be glad to criticize a pencil sketch
of himself which Mr. Cornwell might airmail to him. He is a fine man and most help-
ful. I suggest that if you decide to have either one in the painting (more or less
as incidental background figures) for heaven's sake have both in. I also suggest you
write each one your plan and they may be able to help you with other photos (though
I doubt it), also with data on the uniforms, etc. But remember, Kissinger's memory
isn't too good and he's not well educated; Moran is better. I really think it would
be nice to have them in the painting, representing as it were, all the privates who
offered their bodies for the experiments. And since a half dozen others of them are
still living (though all but Moran and Kissinger volunteered at least in part for the
money) in your descriptive folder re the painting you might say that “Kissinger and
Moran were inserted to represent all of the brave soldiers who volunteered,” etc.

This booklet by Peabody was published by the Dept. of Public Education.
American Museum of Natural History, New York City. I wrote them for a copy. They
only had their own but I finally got a copy from Dr. Peabody (present address, Dr.
James E. Peabody, 281 Lowell Ave., Newtonville, Mass.) He may have one for you if
you sent for it. If not, borrow one from the museum. But remember that there are
a number of minor errors in Dr. Peabody's version (as there seems to be in everybody's!)
For example, Peabody's versions of Lazear's illness, and of Kissinger on page 10,
are very dubious:

I also enclose a small copy of a photo of Dr. Agramonte taken around
1900-1901 (?). It is autographed by him in 1902. Note his uniform. It seems to be
identical with that of Dr. Pinto (#2) with a cross on the collar and some sort of
insignia on the shoulder straps. Whether they were the insignia of any rank I do
not know. Gen. Truby will know, also Gen. Kean. This photo of Agramonte is the
one in Kelly's book, 1906 edition, page. 272.

In summary then I am lending you the following photos (1) hospital corps,
(2) names of corps, (3) Moran - formal photo taken in recent years, (4) snapshot of
Moran in 1940, (5) Moran and Kissinger with Dr. Hutchison in 1940, (6) formal photo
of Kissinger taken in recent years, (7) 3 snapshots of Kissinger taken by me in 1938,
(8) small photo of Agramonte in uniform. Please return them at your leisure.

9)Dodge auto news re Kissinger
10) Sat Eve Post re Moran

I am writing today to (1) Mrs. Lazear, (2) Gen. Truby, (3) Gen. Kean,
(4) Dr. Cummings. I think it likely that Mrs. Lazear might even have one of Dr.
Lazear's actual uniforms. At least I will ask her and if so she might be sufficiently
anxious to have him accurately portrayed as to be willing to have the uniform photo-
graphed in Santa Barbara and a copy sent you. I'm sure she'd never lend it to you.
Mr. George A. Kellogg
- 3 -
February 20, 1941
But perhaps a California representative of yours might do her the honor of actually
calling on her and presenting your request discretely. The same might be said of
Major Reed. His son, General Walter RussellLawrence Reed, lives in Washington, D. C. Perhaps
he or his mother (still living) has his uniform. I can ask Miss Agramonte about her
father's uniform when I see her next month.

As to Miss Clara Maass (so spelled by Dr. Albertini) she was a native of
Orange, New Jersey, aged 25, a nurse employed at Las Animas Hospital. Remember that
she had no part in the experiments of Reed et al (i.e. the army commission) but
volunteered for the later experiments of Guiteras et al who in Aug. 1901 (not 1900)
were trying to verify the commission's work. I have no doubt that by writing the
reference librarian of the Public Library in Orange, you would get much data on her,
also perhaps a photograph of her. I believe, but am not sure, that she had been an
army nurse. Gens. Kean and Truby will know. On page 29 of Chapter 4, U. S. Senate
Document 822 (61st Congress, vol. 61 - 3rd session) the official document regarding all
the yellow fever experiments (it is in the New York Public Library) it says that Miss
Clara Maass served as a trained nurse in the Medical Dept. of the Army during the
Spanish War, later served as a trained nurse in Las Animas Hospital, volunteered and
was bitten by infected mosquitos Aug. 14 and died Aug. 18, 1901. (This also is partly
incorrect; she took sick Aug. 18 and died Aug. 24, 1901 - See American Medicine
Nov. 23, 1901, page 809).

Albertini and the U. S. Senate Document spell her name Maass but in the
New York Times for Sunday, Aug. 25, 1901 (page 1, I think - I have a photostatic copy)
under the heading “The Third Mosquito Victim” is a description of her death. Her
name is there spelled Maas (one s). It states that she was a daughter of Mrs. H. A.
Maas of 344 Main St. East Orange was 25 years old and had been a nurse for 5 years.
During the Spanish War she was in camp at Jacksonville and Savannah and later went
to Cuba and the Phillipines, again to Cuba and her death. Her sister, Miss Sophie
Maas, tried to get to her death-bed. Perhaps in East Orange they have a memorial to
her and perhaps her sister still lives and has her uniform! Doubtless the librarian
can give you the dope.

I have at hand a copy of a speech given by Albertini, Sept. 28, 1936 when
the cardboard plaques were unveiled in Las Animas. In this speech Albertini says,
“I witnessed in Dr. Finlay's house, No. 110 Aguacate Street, the presentation of the
Commission to the great Cuban sage who delivered to Dr. Reed a small soap-dish with
eggs, etc.” I hadn't noticed that sentence before. I must find out if he recalls the
exact date in August when this occurred and how many of the commission actually
visited Finlay. Did he tell you? Albertini was not helpful to me.

I am returning your films. Thank you very much for letting me have copies.
However I wonder if you couldn't have your company photographer take a real good
5 x 7 or 8 x 10 of each preliminary sketch. I'd very much like to send one not only
to Mrs. Lazear but also to Gen. Truby, to Kissinger and Moran and Miss Agramonte. I
think the small snapshots are hardly impressive enough to stimulate the interest of
those you hope to get valuable data from! What do you think? After you left I kicked
myself in the pants for not having run them up to our photo dept. We could have had
them really photoed in 10 minutes. I suspect Mr. Cornwell may seriously object to
Mr. George A. Kellogg
- 4 -
February 20, 1941
letting any photos of preliminary sketches out but if he knows to whom they are to
go he may realize that it would be useful.

Also please send me a few of the small reproductions (black and white)
of the Osler and Beaumont paintings. I think I can insert them in some of the above
letters to show the folks how fine and artistic your project is. I fear me that some
interested parties may not cooperate without a little persuasion, fearing the
commercial aspect of the affair. I suggest you in due time send Truby, Kissinger,
Moran, Kean and Mrs. Lazear, also Dr. Peabody, colored reproductions (unframed)
so that they can see the quality of the work.

Now to answer your letters. I am returning a few of the snapshots you
sent but could I keep the 4 of the old patio? I'd love to keep the copies of the
Cuban articles re your visit. May I? I think they are marvelous and so amusing in
the light of what we all know. But boy, oh boy, have you all gotten yourself
(unwittingly) into a mess! Either you promised too much (too many pleasant Cuban
drinks?) or they wangled you into seeming to promise more than you can ever (honestly)
come across with! I am sure you will know that I believe that Finlay's claims have
been too much ignored and I plan to emphasize his contribution. But in giving Finlay
his just desserts we mustn't do to Walter Reed et al what Finlay believed they did to
him:

Please don't let all the controversial data confuse you. This is the
dope in very simple terms. Finley had a swell idea; it was correct in the main
points that a certain mosquito was the cause. But he couldn't even prove it to the
very Cuban colleagues who ever since have been bowing down to him as a god. And why
couldn't he prove it in 19 years of work? He inoculated 102 patients; he claimed to
have produced 16 positive cases of experimental yellow fever. None of them were
severe or classical. Assuming they were all 16 cases of yellow fever (which they
probably weren't!) none of these patients were quarantined. All were living and
moving about Havana and environs and all (if they had yellow fever) might just as well
have gotten it naturally like everybody else was getting it (through some other mos-
quitos than Dr. Finley's). That is why nobody, not even the Cubans (who later
swallowed Finlay hook, line and sinker!) accepted his data. For the same reason
Reed wasn't at all satisfied with Lazear's first 3 cases; Carroll and Lazear got
the disease but neither was quarantined; only Dean was quarantined and it was that
one case - Dean's - and not really Carroll's or Lazear's that convinced Reed that
Lazear had been on the right track. The Preliminary Note by Reed et al, without the
follow up work done at Camp Lazear, would have been laughed at just as much as
Finley was laughed at for 19 years. That's the dope in a nut shell and don't let
Mr. Cornwell or anybody else persuade you otherwise. If you want to read the cold
(too cold) argument look up the following in your own medical library:
(1) J.A.M.A., May 23, 1903, p. 1429 - “The Transmission of Yellow Fever”
by Carroll. Herein Carroll takes Finlay's experiments apart and shows he could not
have produced a single case of yellow fever.
(2) J.A.M.A. June 13, 1903, page 1659 - Finlay's letter to the editor
of the A.M.A. objecting violently to Carroll's article.
Also same pages - Agramonte's letter to the editor agreeing partly
with Carroll but suggesting that Carroll had been too critical and that Finlay was
a swell guy, after all. (This letter got Agramonte in dutch with both sides!)
Mr. George A. Kellogg
- 5 -
February 20, 1941
(3) Medical Record, Aug. 31, 1901, page 343. Another letter by Finlay
who was by now claiming more and more and getting madder and madder!

You must read the above. It won't take 30 minutes. Also you and Mr.
Cornwell should read the following for background notes; they are very interesting
popular articles:
Agramonte - Annals Int. Med. Aug. 1923.
Ireland - The Conquest of Y. F. The Military Surgeon, Feb. 1929.
Kean - Walter Reed (some real dope) Military Surgeon, Mar. 1928.
Agramonte - Military Surgeon, Nov. 1930.
Agramonte - Scientific Monthly, Dec. 1930 (not the Dec. 1915 one I
loaned you) These are all vital for you to see, most interesting
and entertaining, written in a popular vein and describe dramatically
the places, scenes and reactions of the men involved. If you read
them, you can't possibly be satisfied to give to the American audience
the type of painting originally planned.

Now as to the Cubans. You sure are in the soup there! How can you
possibly get out of it unless you paint two versions? If you want to avoid the
condemnation of all concerned that's all you can do and I suggest you gracefully
label the Finlay Scene “Conquest of Yellow Fever I - Dr. Finlay meets the U.S.
Army Commission, Aug. 1900”.

“Conquest of Yellow Fever II - The U.S. Army Yellow Fever Board dis-
covers the cause of yellow fever: Dr. Lazear inoculating Dr. Carroll.”

I think that plan would be swell and if you present the Cubans with the
first version (preferably via my little museum, says I) you can get out of part of
your trouble. It beats all how, with every honorable intent, a man can get into a
pickle without knowing why. I did the same thing when I went to Cuba, had no idea
they were mad, but because I stuck up for Reed et al they were not overjoyed to
help me. I got no dinner parties, I can assure you!! But I have since heard that
they learned to respect my knowledge because they didn't fool me.

Before you finally decide on having the scene in front of the officers'
porch be sure to get Kean's and Truby's opinion. If you're not going to have it
on the porch why not have it in front of “Reed's little laboratory”; as a matter of
fact Carroll's inoculation by Lazear was doubtless done in the lab; if you depict
it in front of “Reed's lab” it will be just that much more nearly correct. But I
leave this to your conscience as modified or fortified by Kean and Truby. If they
don't squawk, the comments of Reed's son, Mrs. Lazear, Gen. Ireland, Moran and
Kissinger and others closely interested parties will be relatively less important.
Kean and Truby are the watchdogs for truth whom you should get on your side. They
are reasonable men and will doubtless agree to a certain amount of artistic license.
One more point - would Kissinger and Moran have been sitting on the porch in the
presence of superior officers? Perhaps they would have been “at ease.” Doubtless
they would have been looking on with great interest and not casually. It will be
easy to find out from Kissinger and Moran but I won't write either of them till you
decide whether to put them in it or not. Then I'll be glad to write to them.
Mr. George A. Kellogg
February 20, 1941

One more comment: In the Cuban version can't you depict Reed otherwise
than with hat in hand, as it were coming to Finlay “with hat in hand,” swallowing
Finlay's oracular words with never an idea of his own! Why not more action, Reed
looking at the mosquito dish or shaking hands with Finlay or some such. Make Reed
less the suppliant and more the equal (he was much the scientific superior) of
Finlay, and give Lazear more place!

I enclose an article in the Sat. Eve Post, Aug. 5, 1939, re Kissinger.
Popular articles on Moran appeared in the Literay Digest for Jan. 14, 1928 and in
the World's Work for Dec. 1927.
Yours for some more rows with the genial Cubans!
